response.answer_text: With google, they do.  Or they did when I interviewed with them twice. I never had issues with interviewing with any company. I worked at amazon, Expedia and a handful of other companies that weren’t a “walk in the park” to get in. However, after that question about grades in college in each interview with the Mountain View , I was told the typical: “Thanks for your time. At this point, we think we will no longer need to continue…blah, blah, blah.” I was in the top 10% of my high school and as a result got into the best public university locally: the UW. However, after choosing to go the private route, I decided I would never go to graduate school (or felt I didn’t have the need). So, I stopped caring about my grades towards the end of my Freshman year. I thought all I needed was enough to graduate. Well, I was wrong 10+ years later. If I would have done better, I may have been working at Google right now. I interviewed with them in 2001–02. Check out the stock at the time:  I’m thinking life may have been much less stressful 20 years later, but now I’ll never know. Since “grades didn’t matter” to me at that time. At the same time, when I look back on that decision and also the decision to leave Amazon, I found out that with the other companies, grades did NOT matter. It never came up once. I worked for amazon — grades NEVER came up once in the interviews. Networking was key for that position. The same for Expedia. Did it matter for my two businesses I started? Not. At. All. I rose to six figures within the first year for both, but grades had nothing to do with either success. Later, I had the urge to go to graduate school ironically. However, as I learned, I couldn’t get into the top ones - which are the only ones I would have tried to enter. But since I screwed the pooch (with my marks) in college, I basically failed to have the option many years later. Interestingly, I did work for a company that Google eventually acquired. So, I guess if I failed to have the misfortune of going through the dotcom burst and didn’t move to a satellite city, maybe I would be working for Google in NYC now? So, maybe there’s a way without grades? Nevertheless, as you can see, they DO matter in many cases. It just depends on what path you take. (Update) p.s. Year later, I’m somewhat grateful I didn’t end up at Google. I’ve heard how sexist and pampered they are internally. It reminds me a bit of my time at Expedia. While we never were shown to be sexist, there were times at Expedia where I questioned if I was even working. While life has been challenging, I can say there’s always “something to do.” After many years of dealing with issue after issue (even some of the pain I’m dealing with now after thinking nothing could get worse), I’ve found that having “issues” can sometimes make life even more rewarding.

“We need you to lead our intern program this summer.” “Do we have an intern program?” “Nope, but you’ll come up with something.” My first opportunity as a manager was hiring several interns and developing a program to teach them to sell. I was 24 years old and this was my first time interviewing and selecting talent. I visited two major universities after posting a job description and pre-selecting candidates for interview panels. With no prior experience in hiring and only a few open positions, I set about limiting applications to those I would meet in person. My company was Fortune 10 and put a heavy emphasis on GPA. Our brand name was strong and we felt like we could recruit the best of the best.  I knew this because of how much grief I took for my weak 2.95 overall GPA when I interviewed three years prior. Every interviewer dug into why my grades weren’t higher, so much that I was surprised when they actually made me an offer. After two days of interviews, I only filled 3 of the 4 slots. Most of the candidates I met with were rigid and limited in extracurricular activities. With this group, the higher the GPA, the harder it was to keep the conversation going. I came across plenty of intelligent people but struggled to see them interacting with customers. After the last day of panel interviews, we had an information session open to all students. We bought some pizzas and managers were available to talk about the company to anyone interested in attending. A young man approached me at this session. He hadn’t been selected for an interview but was very interested in our company. He gave me his resume and I realized quickly why I hadn’t met him. He had a 3.0 GPA in Management and we were looking for 3.5 or higher with an Engineering degree. Yes, it seems ridiculous looking back that we wanted a 3.5 for a sales internship. To understand, picture Google advertising for a sales and marketing internship today. They will receive thousands of resumes and can pick the very best. Kids will apply because Google on your resume nearly guarantees that you land a full time position out of college. I worked for GE twenty years ago, at a time when GE made magazine covers for Most Admired Company and our CEO, Jack Welch, had just been named CEO of the Century by Fortune. In other words, it was easy to find high GPA candidates who wanted GE on their resume and they didn’t care what the assignment was. Back to this young man, I tried to let him down nicely and told him the requirements for the position and he handled it like a champ. He smiled, said he understood and then asked politely if he could ask me a few questions. Sure, I thought. The pizza is paid for and my flight isn’t until tomorrow. “This is a sales internship, correct?” “Yes, it is.” “What will you expect of an intern?” “Well, you would be prospecting from a list of potential targets. You role is to set up appointments for our seasoned sales reps by cold calling.” “Got it. Do the other candidates you’ve selected have experience cold calling?” “Uh, not that I can recall. No.” “Can I tell you about my background?” He went on to tell me about his first job which was selling door to door. He told me about how humbling the experience was at first and how he hit 200 houses every day, rain or shine. He walked me through the importance of a good opening, how to lead with a smile and a question, how he overcome objections and the importance of mindset when you’re having a bad day. He further explained how he did this job while putting himself through college. In fact, he had several jobs while taking classes which made it challenging to spend as much time studying as some other kids. He then told me about his fraternity and the roles he held, including two semesters as President. He explained how his fraternity had built his social skills and what he learned about leadership from running a house filled with 50 guys. Oh, by the way, he was a collegiate athlete which was also a significant time constraint. “OK, you win. Want a job?” He accepted and all four started on the same day. Three of the four had an average of 3.8 GPA and our door to door salesman brought the average down a few points. You can probably guess who came out on top. From day one, my boy with the average GPA ran circles around the more accomplished students. Yes, he had specific experience that gave him a head start but he had something much more important. Mindset. When a customer said no to him, he moved on. He didn’t let rejection define him as he was accustomed to failures. He looked at these small failures as opportunities to learn and tweak his pitch with the next phone call. His peers saw it much differently. They were so accustomed to winning that the daily parade of rejection was debilitating. They took every rejection personally and it was apparent in the volume of calls they made. On a daily basis, our fraternity President was making twice the number of outbound calls. The others were so paralyzed by potential rejection that they took way too much time preparing for their phone calls and then second guessing themselves after every call. Rather than playing the numbers game and grinding, they deliberately slowed the process so as not hear “no” as often in a day. In psychological terms, this is called self-handicapping and is a coping mechanism to avoid damage to self esteem. Of the four interns, we only made one permanent offer and he had the lowest GPA in the group. Does this mean I never hired a candidate with a high GPA? Absolutely not. One of the best hires I ever made was to an honors student from Georgia Tech just a few B’s away from a 4.0. He also held high level roles in several organizations and played competitive basketball. But, even this young man struggled out of the gate, especially with failure and not having a definitive path to achieving results. I’ve seen many hires with a strong GPA struggle with the many indirect paths to success in a career. They are used to following instructions, completing their assignments, putting in the work and getting a perfect grade. In business, there is no one prescribed way of getting results. College professors are interested in the path you take to a result as well as the result. In business, there is only the result. Most managers are indifferent on your path. Some kids with perfect grades struggle when you won’t give them a prescribed plan to achieve that result. They chafe at the lack of direction, which is a hallmark in business. No one is going to hold your hand. I like hiring people who have failed a little in their life and are not paralyzed by it. I especially like people who are not afraid to admit a) That they failed, b)Why they failed and c) What they learned from it. If your grades aren’t the greatest, own it. Explain why it happened. Did you have a miserable semester where you didn’t apply yourself? Own it. Then tell me how that humbling experience forced you into better habits and what you learned that will make you a better asset to my company. The last thing I will say about grades is that two years after graduation, no one will give a damn. You probably won’t ever get asked about your GPA once you’ve had some real life experience and opportunity to prove what you can do for a business. Businesses are much more interested in your ability to generate tangible results than grades on an exam. Once you start your first job, no one will care about your GPA. You will be measured against every other person in your role, whether they went to college or not. You will be measured on results. If you had a high GPA, brace yourself for failure. Actually, embrace failure. Welcome failure as an opportunity to learn. Boast about your failures, make fun of yourself a little. This will drive you to try harder and skip the self-handicapping behavior holding you back. Get that first job, kick butt and you’ll be done talking about grades for the rest of your career. Unless, you decide to write an answer on Quora like me. Good luck out there.

Yes. A million times, YES. God, it angers me to no end when I hear older people telling teens and school kids “The grades which you get mean nothing in the long term. Chill, don’t worry!” They’re doing these young people a deep disservice by feeding them comforting but utterly nonsensical pablum which those kids want to hear, never mind that it is highly inaccurate and unfortunately fateful. Because most of these kids heeding that stupid song will pay a high price then, often for the rest of their lives. Let me put it in this way - Doing well in school does not guarantee career success but doing poorly almost always means paying for it dearly. Do not confuse ‘lack of a guarantee’ for insignificance. It’s like driving drunk versus sober. Being sober doesn’t mean you will never have an accident but that doesn’t mean you get sloshed before you take the wheel. Probabilities matter. A lot. Look, as a guy who has worked in some of the most competitive professions, let me spell it out as clearly as I can - We cared A LOT about grades when reviewing college grads for hires. Not only the grades, but the majors in which they graduated. In most cases, the resumes with mediocre grades (say GPAs of less than 3.0 out of 4.0) got screened out right at the start. Reviewing resumes is not an exercise in pleasure when it’s an additional task to your ‘60 hours a week’ job already - so in most cases, we had little patience and threw those resumes out right away. You’re not even getting a peep through a crack in the door, forget getting through it! This isn’t some kind of random fetish. Because I’ll spell out the two key reasons why grades matter - Knowledge of the subject - “Son, don’t feed me this horse dung that you’re a master at accounting or operations when you have Cs in those courses.”I remember a friend of mine in business school saying to me “Allen, just because you get top grades in finance, doesn’t mean you know that subject better than the rest of us.” - “Umm, actually that’s EXACTLY what it means!”. How else do you expect someone to evaluate your knowledge of a subject? By taking them at their word? By divining it from their face?Show of hands please by those among you who would like to be operated on by a young surgeon who barely scraped through med school?How about hiring a lawyer who passed her bar exam only on the fifth attempt? And who among you will hire an accountant who you knew had barely managed to make it over the line in his CPA exam?Any takers?Oh I’ll bet that even the ones who most think that grades or theoretical knowledge don’t matter will not touch those three persons mentioned above with a ten foot pole. Not when it comes to actually making a decision on who to trust their life, liberty or money with!Make no mistake - If you want to be a Wall Street banker, you had better bloody aced your accounting and finance courses. If you want to get admitted into a Ph.D program for physics at M.I.T., you had better kicked ass in your undergrad at that.An unmistakable marker of discipline - This one is even more important than the first one. In the corporate world, there is an absolute premium placed on diligence.When I see a resume of a kid who has top grades, not only does it tell me that this fellow knows his stuff, it tells me that he is much more likely to apply himself to the job with dedication. Hard work and discipline matter. Top grades are not merely a marker of knowledge but one of conscientiousness. It is a key signal which says “I am the kind of person who can apply him/herself with single-minded determination over an extended period - and you can count on me to do that in my job if you hire me.” I cannot emphasize that point enough.You screw up your grades in high school and it has a ripple effect - you have a significantly lower chance of getting into a top university - which in turn translates into a lesser career. Repent then at leisure. As a case in point, why do you think that Jewish and Asian Americans are at the top of the socioeconomic food chain? Because they eat something special for breakfast? It’s because growing up, those kids have their parents riding their asses to do well in school. Those habits are then woven into them from the start - and that then continues into their careers as adults. And yes, I can see the ones talking about top entrepreneurs not doing all that well at school. But they are exceptions to the rule and it is not a wise approach to bet on you being that “one in a thousand” exception. So yes, for goodness sake care about your grades like the blazes! Because the habits which you develop as a child and as a teen, will mold your very character. If you think that you’re going to be all sloppy and uncaring for the first fifteen or twenty years on this earth and then all of a sudden just get up like magic in your twenties and be diligent? Really? You’ll find your old habits hard to shake off. Very hard, because that slovenliness has been virtually seared into your very character by then. As the old saying goes in metaphorical terms “The child foretells the man like the morning foretells the day.”

I’m going to answer this exactly the same way that I tell my students. Your grade only really matter for the traditional path and for a small number of research jobs and careers. What matters a lot more is your approach to life: Do you always try to do your best? (Do you actually try at all?)If you get stuck do you try to solve the problems other ways or just give up? (Also called “grit” which is the current in word.)Are you willing to try things and see if it works out?Are you curious about new things?The thing is that if these are true then students almost always have fairly good grades. These are the things that matter not grades most of the time. That being said here are the times that grades matter: Your high school grades matter when applying to university BUT if you wait a few year or even just do a university subjects then try to transfer (assuming they accept transfer students) then your high school grades don’t mater any more your entrance exam matters or the grades for the university subject you do.Your university grades matter when you apply for your first job BUT after the first job everyone cares about your work experience NOT your grades.You need good grades for academic scholarships.For research students your grades matter (a lot) until you publish a research paper then your previous research matters more.Basically grades matter at a few specific instances in time when transitioning between phases in life. Grades can save you a few years of “catching up” but in the long run there are other paths to the same thing that take a little bit longer if you are willing to try. This is why some high school drop outs succeed. At school they don’t have the correct attitude to life. They fail, hit rock bottom, go through the school of hard knocks and relatively quickly learn and change who they are then succeed without traditional schooling. The grades try (sometimes badly) to reflect what is important.

This is an ode to all students who have ever gotten B’s, C's, D's (and sometimes even failed). It's a declaration to the kids who calculated the exact number of points they needed to get on their finals in order to pass. This is for all those kids who didn't get extra credit or get placed on honor roll. After years of inadequacy and a lifetime of feeling average and unremarkable, your time has come. Now it’s finally the time to tell you that even if your GPA's lower than 1.2, you can be great. For years, society has placed a disgustingly large stigma on bad grades and an overwhelming importance on good grades. There's a predisposed instinct to strive for A's and cast anything lower to the side, to deem as unworthy. Well, it's time to let the children learn that it's okay not to be an A student, it's okay to fail. Because here's a little secret the older generations are unwilling to divulge to you: it doesn't matter. To all those tight-ass intellectuals out there, it's time to get the facts straight. For all those years that you spent cooped up in the library, poring over facts and stats, soliloquies and Greek mythology, the average scoring kids — the ones partying and getting C's in college — are the ones obtaining the skills that do matter: life experiences. Failing is a life experience. Not getting that A on the exam you spent all night studying for, is an experience. Life experiences are a composite of all the skills necessary to get along in the real world. It's comprised of all those skills that are only learned through failure and the obstacles of life, like how to hold a conversation, get away with a lie or entertain someone you really don't like. It's all those skills that high-paying Fortune 500 companies value above all else. In college, it's all about grades. In the real world, it's about experience, balls and drive. Because once you get past the first job, no one is ever going to ask you about your GPA or how you did on that Psych 215 final. What matters in the real world is your ability to adapt, innovate and get along. There are no scantron sheets or essay exams. There are no TA’s to hold review sessions or to help you practice your presentation. Real life is about how well you can bullshit your way through it, and that's not something taught in a classroom. The greatest thinkers, leaders and entrepreneurs of our time have been the men to defy the rules and take risks. They were the ones getting C's or flunking out. However, their “failures' were not a factor of intelligence, but an inability to be weighed down by grades and superficial markings. Bill Gates, Steve Jobs, Richard Branson, Mark Zuckerberg are just a few of the men who achieved unfathomable amounts of wealth, status and success without ever really succeeding in a classroom. They are the men, that by society’s standards, had failed.With their passion and intelligence, they were able to change the world with nothing more than a bachelor’s degree and a transcript of failing grades (sometimes not graduating at all). These men understood at an early age that just because society, and everyone around them, placed an excessive amount of importance on grades didn’t mean they were right. But it’s not just these extreme examples of eccentric billionaires and tech geniuses that should solidify the results of this finding. It’s about yourself and the gut feelings you have towards what is right and what is wrong. Succeeding in life means following your gut and understanding what a bad decision is. Just because you passed American History with flying colors doesn’t mean you’ll know what to do when your coworker is talking behind your back to your boss. It doesn’t mean you’ll know how to handle an insubordinate or get together a presentation the night before a deadline. The people who do great things are the ones too absorbed in their own ideas to place too much weight on the opinions of others. Why should Steve Jobs spend hours studying someone else’s ideas and breakthroughs when he could be out creating his own? What people fail to see in bad grades is the reason behind them. Why is this person not getting an A? Is this person doing something that is better? “Everybody is a genius. But, if you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree, it’ll spend it’s whole life believing that it is stupid.” Albert Einstein So for all of you preparing for finals, or finishing them with a bitter taste in your mouth, this should be reason enough not to worry. If you are ending the semester with C’s and maybe a few D’s, don’t sweat. There’s plenty of opportunity out there, and it’s the people with the audacity not to care about their grades — the ones who don’t spend their lives in the library and bubbling in correct answer sheets — who will rule the world. Because at the end of it all, it’s really about those people with the most passion.

Imagine you are a corporate recruiter or college admission looking at hundreds of applications for a single spot at your company or university.  Image Source: JDYoung Your job is to find the person with the highest potential to be a successful contributor with the least amount of risk. You know almost nothing about the people represented by the stack of papers on your desk. Maybe you met a few of them at an event and recognize the name. But for most of these applicants, you will only spend 60 seconds or less to see if they meet a minimal threshold to get a deeper look later. But someone needs to narrow down the initial list first. Easiest way to make the first cut? Use GPA.  A GPA is so much more than a collection of grades. It’s actually an important signal that tells someone a lot about your work ethic and your intellectual capacity. What university or company doesn’t want a hard-working, smart person on their team? Sure there are plenty of examples of the Einsteins, Zuckerbergs, and Jobs in the world that succeeded without needing a GPA to prove themselves. But they are the exceptions. Most companies or universities rather take the sure thing than take a gamble because they rather miss the 1 in a million shot to land that unicorn and take someone with a proven GPA. Think about it this way - As a company, you are paying a new graduate $40K-$75K a year and handing over responsibilities that can sometimes impact people’s lives, important business relationships, or expensive deals. As a highly ranked university, you are expected to build a class that maintains the program’s reputation, enriches the experience of other students, and graduates on-time to become successful (and generous) alumni donors. Grades mean everything when you are just getting started in your career. If you struggle with school then you need to invest your time and energy into other valuable or rare skills that Rohan Kamath and Jessica Su mention in their responses. Thank you for reading and remember that there is no shortcut to hard work and discipline whether you decide to invest it in your grades or some other skill. Good luck!

Yes. They do. A lot. I’ll tell you my story. I was occupied with re-writing, editing, dealing with literary agents, and searching a reputed publisher for my novel in my first year of engineering. After struggling for months, I got an intent letter from a good publisher. However, in all of that, I got three subjects back. In the second year of engineering, the ‘start-up fad’ caught hold of my brain. My B-plan and synthesis came into top 30 among 700 applications at the UDGAM, IIT-G. Meanwhile, I started liking a twin of Naina Talwar (from Yeh Jawani Hai Deewani) who recently took admission in my college. However, I was determined. I neglected her as well as my engineering exams and drove my entire focus towards budding the start-up. In all of that, my percentage suffered badly. In the third year, the person who I loved the most in this world, died. My mom and papa had jobs when I was born, and they left me at home with my Grandpa — my everything. When he was on the ventilator, every single ring of my mobile sent chills down my spine. Doctors had informed he was going to die. Any call could have been the ‘news’ call. Therefore, I was scared. Every single second. Perhaps my grandpa knew I would leave everything and come to him. Therefore, he postponed his death a week after my exams. But, in between my exams, another mishap came my way. The publisher withdrew his intent and left me hopeless. He cheated me. Desperate, I became engrossed in sending submissions to more publishers. All of the above, no matter how much I tried, showed their effect on my marks. I got my papers back again. During the last semester of the third year, I realized that establishing and building a start-up is ten times harder than we think. I postponed the idea of starting up. The death of my grandpa was killing me already, but the girl I liked also started giving me pains. Pains out of my own expectations. But pains, nonetheless. Meanwhile a start-up idea that was very similar to mine won the first prize in Ten Minute Million competition at E-Summit, IIT-B. Adding to that, the best company among all those which were supposed to come for recruitments, arrived in the third year itself. I couldn’t sit for the interviews because of my backlog. I felt bad for postponing my start-up, for giving up. I felt bad for giving the key of my self-esteem to the girl I had feelings for. I felt bad for not being able to attend the job interview, even when I’m very good at aptitude tests and communicating. I felt bad, very very bad. But, I elbowed away all the regrets and studied. I studied and studied until one publisher offered me the contract. My grip on the studies loosened a little because of the contract signing and negotiating and publishing works. It resulted in another backlog. I am now in the fourth year. Many reputed companies are coming and hiring and going. More than half of my classmates are placed. People with average marks in aptitude tests, satisfactory communication skills, and poor technical skills are placed. On the other hand, I cannot even sit for the interviews. Minimum CGPA 7.75 and minimum percentage of 60 was the eligibility criteria of 95% of the companies that visited my college. Ninety-five percent! Therefore, I cannot even sit for campus interviews because I have an active backlog and percentage below 60. Frustrated, I recently gave AMCAT. AMCAT is the national employability test attempted by millions. I got 99 percentile in English, 97 percentile in Quantitative Aptitude, 98 percentile in Logical Reasoning, and 79 Percentile in Mechanical Engineering. Overall 93.25 percentile. I was amongst the toppers in three subjects. Yet, yes, yet, the jobs available on AMCAT ‘too’ had the minimum graduation percentage eligibility criteria. People with 80 percentile easily got shortlisted. I didn’t. As a past-time, I researched on the foreign universities and their eligibility criteria and admission processes. I never had plans to go out of India. But maybe I was scared which made me research about that. I dug deeper. Turned out that foreign universities too gave importance to GPA. Canada and the USA and few European universities didn’t even let people with more than eight backlogs apply to their universities. But it made me sick. A good GRE score too couldn’t have gifted me a good university because of my backlogs and low GPA. Mind you, things are similar to some blue-blooded M.Tech and MBA colleges in India. I then decided to chuck it all away and live my life peacefully for a few days. I continued writing. I traveled a bit. I called my old friends. When the suicidal thoughts escaped my mind, I dug my primary school dream. The Indian Navy. I prepared for UPSC CDSE. From my entire college, I was the only person who cracked it. I got a call-letter from SSB Bhopal. But guess what happened… when I entered my graduation marks and an active backlog in their form, they sent me home. No travel reimbursement. No other way to get in. Just go home. I am shattered right now. And to be honest, that is why I’m writing so much. You get sick, you see a doctor. I get sick, I write.  A few lessons that I learned through all these are: No matter how hard the road seems to be. No matter how less a knowledge or experience you think you have into something. If you are working on a great product (in my case: novel) try to do everything on your own (in my case: self-publish) Remember that People will not take your work half as seriously as you would, even if you pay them. Therefore, take it all in your hands and take tiny bits of help from the people who are experienced in that field and learn things on the internet and work your ass off and make it happen. You have the capacity and the resources to do it all by yourself.Pursue hobbies and passions. But, learn to balance. You’ll have to sacrifice a lot of things in order to balance. But one day it will become a habit and you’ll grow and be at peace while others will remain stagnant and stressed.“Patience gives you sweetest fruits” isn’t working in this era. The world is changing very rapidly. You’ll keep thinking and your idea will get old, or it will be implemented by someone else. Therefore, analyze and take quick action. Quick.The hottest girl from your college is already having someone in her life. Pretty girls could be single, but they are never, never, never alone. Even if they always say it. They have a lot of guys around them, distracting them all the time. Therefore, it is completely okay and normal to have a crush on someone, but “Genius is about knowing when to stop” — Charles de Gaulle. Start moving away the moment you feel she is not going to be with you. Period. I’ve learned it the hardest way.Learn from your mistakes; do not repeat them. The most important lesson.People only, only care about the end results. They judge you by your current position. Not by your journey. Sometimes not even by your capability. Just think what went through your head while reading my journey above. “This guy is making excuses,” isn’t it? Exactly. People will think the same when you’ll tell them your story. They won’t give a fuck unless you make poetry or something entertaining out of your failures story. Therefore, paddle inside the water like a duck and do not give excuses.Going against the grain is romanticized. The people who work 9–5 find the grass greener on the other side. They do not know that grass incinerates and whoever walks on it burns his feet. I’m not asking you not to go against the grass. But if you do, please make sure you have a backup plan. And if you are going against the grain while in college itself — simultaneously while studying, then make sure your base is firm and strong. You’ve invested so much time and money into engineering or medical or other popular fields. Learn it properly. You don’t have to top. Just maintain above 65%, and you will be good.CGPA matters. And it matters a lot.Even after bad grades and so many failures, I’m hopeful that one day I will make it. I’m hopeful that life will come on track. Everything gets okay in the end. It really does. But, if you have a bad CGPA, then my friend… it could take years of enthusiastic struggle and millions of heartbreak survival to get at the place where your friends with a good CGPA will already be seen enjoying. __________________________________________________________________ Have a look at this article with 377k+ views and 16k+ upvotes Pratik Shelke's answer to What are the mistakes that I should not do in my 4-year engineering college life?

I have completed my high school and under graduate studies from India. Moved abroad for my MBA. Let me give you an overview of my grades - Class 10th - 2005 (CBSE Board) - 78.4 percent. This is an extremely average or a below average score considering that people sleep walk through exams and still score in excess of 90 percent. I had to change schools because I couldn’t science at my first school because I did not meet their criteria of 80 percent. Class 12th - 2007 (CBSE Board) - 77 percent. Again, below average and did not make it to any good science or engineering college in the country. Failed in all the entrance exams for engineering. Parents were extremely disappointed. Well they do matter! I can tell you about what I observed during my 4 years of college. My answer would definitely be biased towards IITB CSE (although it will mostly be the same scenario for different streams and colleges). TL;DR : If you have good grades, many things in life (be it getting into good universities, or getting placed) become somewhat easier and less stressful for you. The effect of GPA is least in the case of company placements as the only role GPA plays (most of the times) in company placements is that of Round 1 filtering and rest of the criteria is based on your performance in interviews and/or tests. However,Some companies tend to directly hire people who have good grades (By good I mean the creamy layer of the people who applied for the job). E,.g. if the company has vacancy for say 10 people, then it may fill 3–4 positions directly based on grades. If you lie in that creamy layer, then you may not have to walk the tough road of interview and tests to get placed.For companies like Google, Facebook etc. which receive myriad of job applications, even the Round-1 Filtering can be really tough, and having exceptional grades definitely give you an edge in those cases. Generally, for off-campus applications, you need to have good grades even for Round-1 filtering.If you want to go to grad schools, then grades matter a lot.If you are applying for Masters, then grades are a very important criteria for judgement of your application. In this case, what matters more is your relative grade compared to your fellow mates in your college who are also applying to the same programme. So even if say you have ~ 9.5 GPA but ten of your fellow mates have greater than that, then you may get rejected.If you are applying for PhD, things are bit different. In this case, your publication list and your letter of recommendations (which are also correlated with GPA to be honest) matter more.Grades also have several indirect effects. E.g. if you have good grades, you will get good advisors (as many advisors filter project requests directly based on grades) for your projects, and if you work with good advisors, you will get better letter of recommendations. Also, working with good advisors results in higher chances of getting your work published at top-tier conferences (hence my point of correlation in 2b)Do grades matter for entirety of your life ? No. As you move ahead in your career, your more recent records/accomplishments matter more than your past ones. E.g. if you get a job, and work in that company for two years, and apply somewhere else - the new recruiters will likely be more interested in what you did in your last job, rather than your grades from 2 years back. Hence, good grades is definitely something you should aim for during your college. However, bad grades is not a dead end. It’s just a matter of time, after which no one would care to know about what grades you got in your undergrad curriculum.

Unfortunately, there is no simple answer to your question. Grades may matter for some and may not for some. Does it depend on what are grades being utilized for? Probably, yes! That said, the consensus is that good grades will never hurt. If you were applying for a job that needs to meet specific prerequisites and you have high grades in those courses; it will impact your application positively. The opposite holds true as well. There are certain professions such as doctors and nurses where grades are significant. What do grades tell? It simply reveals how hungry are you to succeed (on paper or in real life?). It shows how competitive you are and maybe your motivation to succeed. How do people get higher grades? When I was in my undergraduate program (Penn State), a lot of people had far better grades than me mainly because they took a lot of cupcake classes that had an easy A written on it. Since the classes required a very minimal amount of work, it allowed them to get a GPA boost. In fact, at one point I felt that getting a good GPA is very similar to playing a videogame.Some people would purposely take harder classes in summer to get a better GPA or at times to even pass the course. Historically and statistically, summer semesters are easier to deal with. Why? Because most of the professors are gone and some graduate student is teaching during that time.There were others who would wait semesters to get the professor/instructor of their choice (See RateMyProfessors.com – Find and rate your professor or campus.).Then there were some who would take AP exams before coming to college and get a waiver for some of the known hard classes. I am not saying that AP’s are easy, but at least they are standardized.Some students took classes where one of the TA’s would be their friend, and I know at least at two instances where the TA gave question papers to a couple of students. Not that this happens all the time, but some students do get an edge if not an entire set of exam questions.What do grades don’t tell? It doesn’t say anything about the financial situation of the student. I remember how some students used to sell their wardrobe because they didn’t have enough money to pay their tuition.It doesn’t say anything about what a student might be going through. A student may be going through a hard time because of a death in the family, or something unfortunate happened to them. I distinctly remember how I was encouraged to withdraw from the semester (after paying 16k out of which none was coming back to me) because I had to miss two weeks of classes due to a family emergency. I am not saying every professor is like that, but there are still many out there who set their rules in the stone. (By the way, I didn’t withdraw :)… I did get a big F in my Basketball class)It doesn’t say anything about the background of a student and his/her family. For example, I am the first person to go to college in my entire lineage. Imagine, how hard it would have been for my parents to help me do my homework or help me learn anything beyond grade 6 books.I know students who would try different hacks to find the right balance between academics and their financial conditions. For example, some colleges charge you flat-rate tuition beyond a certain number of credits. Penn State had flat-rate tuition beyond 12 credits. I remember taking 22 credits in one semester (18 credits was the max load you could take during fall/spring semester, and I had to get the department approval to do that). On average, students would take 15–16 credits, However, almost no recruiter/company will understand such ROI because we were students. People need excel spreadsheets and powerpoint presentation before they can take you seriously.Grades don’t talk about your bravery where you took a class that was entirely out of your league, and you still took the risk without any care for the grade just because you wanted to learn something new. Most of my general education classes were beyond my league, and even though my grades were not so great, it still helped me in becoming well-rounded.Grades don’t talk about how students bust their ass working a 20–40-hour job to take some of the burden off their parent's shoulder.On top of all this, I was an international student which means I had even more restrictions on what I could do and what I cannot. Having someone around you vs. having your loved ones 9000 miles far is a whole different situation.Physical disabilities can militate your success. I am legally blind from one eye, and no one has an idea about how it impacts me and my studies. I sometimes find it hard to look at one thing because of the amount of stress my one eye has to take. I was always bullied about my eye since my early childhood because my brain doesn't know how to communicate with my left eye and it went on during my college years as well. It affects your circle of friends and your mind is not the same as others.From a college perspective, as long as you graduate, you should be fine, but there has to be some rationale behind low grades. If you were studying all day and still got bad grades, then there is a problem. But, if you were merely using the college setting as a playground to fail and learn, it's a different ball game. At least this was the case with me. I was apprehensive about my grades after I finished college. Luckily, there was someone out there who still wanted to hire me. During my master's program, my GPA has always stayed in the honors list range not because I am great at what I do but purely because I understand how GPAs work. For me, low grades don't matter as long as someone can provide me with a plausible explanation. People can have low grades for a variety of reasons as I mentioned above. Now, one can argue that maybe I should not have taken too many classes. However, things are not so simple in a student’s head. I sometimes wish colleges made an effort to understand a Student’s brain better. The most critical element in a college is the student itself and guess what? Most don’t care to get that right. College/School to me was nothing more than a chemistry lab where I performed different experiments. A lot of them ultimately failed but what I learned from those failures are unfortunately not recorded on transcripts. Don’t worry too much about grades. Be open-minded and keep learning… “[You] will either find a way or make one” (Hannibal)

Do grades really matter to make it big? Yes, they do. Are grades sufficient for making it big? No, they aren’t. Are grades necessary for making it big? No, they aren’t. Grades are like most other things (your college, previous work experience, communication skills, existing network, IQ, EQ etc) one of the parameters that together define your future. Taken in isolation, all of them help and matter but none of them are either sufficient or necessary. What we need to realize is that we all live under some constraints (money, time, bandwidth, aspirations etc), so we all have to continuously make choices, often without knowing whether or not it is the most optimal choice. But that is the point, it is okay to make a sub-optimal choice, as long as it is your choice and not you floating through life / avoiding making a choice. E.g. I had long ago decided that grades don’t matter to me. Did it hurt me? Yes. I am sure a lot of people would have thought I wasn’t very smart considering I was barely scraping through in both my undergrad and grad. May be. with better grades I would have been able to spend more time with the best students / profs. May be, I would have studied in IIM A (my first choice) instead of FMS (my second choice). May be, I would have joined a consulting firm (my first choice at that time) instead of a telecom company. But I knew that MBA wasn’t very important to me, in-fact I publicly claimed that if I don’t get through IIM A / FMS, I would work for a couple of years and then decide if I want to do an MBA. Similarly at FMS, the company that I would join wasn’t important to me, I knew I would drop out of it soon enough. So, I let go of grades and I focused on things that mattered to me. On reading, on building lifelong friendship with many people, on experiences, on Age of Empires, on Cricket, on helping others, on taking long walks and discussing existential questions. By no measure, have I made it big, but I do I think I have done fairly okay. And I know (just like you probably do) people of both kinds, who chose / didn’t choose to work on grades, and have done pretty well. The common factor being that they chose depending on what they thought was the right thing to do at that point in time. Conclusion: Do grades matter? To some they do, to some they don’t. Don’t let someone else make that decision for you, ask others and listen to them carefully, and then make the decision for yourself.

When you apply for a job, at least in a tech or scientific field, the GPA may serve as a screener. Company X only wants job candidates with a GPA of 3.0 or better, while Company Y insists on 3.5 or higher, on a 4.0=A scale. Certainly some companies in some fields will be so impressed by your charisma, recommendations and family connections that the only requirement is passing. Graduate schools will likely have a formula to decides who gets in. I saw the actual secret formula at one graduate department in the 1970s. You got points for a high Graduate Record Exam, points for your GPA tempered by the quality of your undergrad school and its degree of grade inflation, the difficulty of the courses you took, the quality of recommendations, and whether you had done a research project. Points were then added to the total if the applicant was in certain minority groups. So a high GPA can help you get into a quality grad school, and to get a plum assignment in that school, like research assistant to a prominent faculty member. This can eventuate in a greater likelihood of getting a good job after graduate school. A high GPA in a terminal undergrad program can help you get a good first job. After graduate school or after the first job, no one will care whether you were at the top or bottom of your class, although it might help in a job search if you mentioned academic honors. Employers or clients will be more interested in your work experience and job history.

I assume you're asking about employment. The rule of thumb I've heard that has been true in my experience is that if it's your first job out of college, employers care about your GPA, and any relevant work experience you may have picked up while in school. That's it. They don't care about the individual grades you got in your classes. One thing I tried, though I have no idea how well it succeeded, is also putting what my GPA was inside my major on my resume, since it was a bit better than my overall GPA. After your first post-graduate job, no one cares about your GPA. They care about your relevant work experience. In terms of everything else, grades are relative. It depends on the scoring system the schools use, and how strictly they adhere to it. If grades are based on the teacher's knowledge of the subject, then it's a matter of whether the school is good at hiring teachers who really know their stuff or not. If it's based on demonstrated knowledge to a standard curriculum, then it may be more of an absolute score, where bad teachers will tend to produce low scoring classes, but then it's a matter of whether the curriculum is rigorous or not. In any case, trying to exceed expectations, I think, puts you in good stead in life, regardless of what the scoring system is. This requires some original thinking, and initiative.

Short answer: Yes, absolutely! Never think otherwise. Don’t ever listen to that drunk senior, sitting outside his room and preaching you during your first week at college, about how grades don’t matter and things like cultural fests, student body posts, sports etc are the only things you need on your resume. Never ever. Disclaimer: Before you read ahead, I want to make completely sure, that in no way I am suggesting that college fests, extra curricular, sports etc don’t matter. They do, but the line ‘GPA doesn’t matter, X is the thing you should do at college.’ is the single biggest misleading line, I have heard during my college years. They are playing with your college lives, most probably because they didn’t do much with theirs, or because they were really great at juggling things, and you might not be. Now, why GPA would matter, A lower GPA from the beginning would lower your self esteem and you would be drifting to even lower GPAs in the next years. Now, I am not saying you can’t pull yourself back up, but trust me it’s not that simple to wash off your sins. Pulling your GPA in the later years of your college life is extremely tough.Beginning from second or third year, you would mostly be doing group projects. And, if you have a lower GPA, you would have high chances of ending up with groups with lower average GPAs, less motivation for the work, a half-finished project, and again a lower grade on the subject. It’s a cycle.Now, don’t you want to bag that much talked about internship in your third year? A lot of companies, sometimes even after taking tests, end up shortlisting people with higher GPAs and top students in the class for interviews. So, you might end up not even having a shot at that dream company, no matter how good you were with your concepts.Do you want to pursue research? Most of the professors would prefer students with something to prove, and the easiest way to prove your mettle to your professors is a good grade at their course and a good GPA. Also, professors already know students with good GPAs from their peers and you would have a higher chance at getting that project you want.What about that MS/PhD at the top universities that you want to go to next? Your GPA is the single most trustworthy metric to gauge from your resume for someone who doesn’t know you (unless you really have good research papers, noteworthy projects, and wonderful recommendations). And, remember, now you are not competing with just your college, but a very large talent pool, possibly the entire world. If you don’t have great research/projects on your resume, then nothing else will stand out from someone else, except your GPA. A good GPA will at least give you a shot of being looked at from a heavy pile of resumes dumped every year.I am not insinuating that, GPA is the only things that matters, but, it is one of the most important things that does.

Senior year, he applies to software engineering jobs, and gets referrals to all the best companies. He solves several hundred questions on LeetCode, and gets a great job offer right out of college. For Jim, grades weren’t important; what mattered were friendships and interview prep. If you have great grades, you will find that grades matter a lot. If you have great work experience, you will find that experience critical to your success. If you have great people skills, you will find that matters a lot too. The most successful people recognize their strengths early on, and choose goals and activities that leverage their strengths.

Are we talking high school or college? GPA has different values depending on your current level of education? Let me start by just saying that many people believe a top GPA, the elusive 4.0, can get you into top schools like Harvard, Stanford, etc. This is not true. So many factors go into the college admissions game, even when I earned straight A’s other students went on to much better universities.  High school: Do you want graduate top of your class? Do you want to get into an honor program? Do you want to go to a top college? Do you want a scholarship? If you care about any of these then yes, GPA matters. Let me tell you my story about how GPA impacted my high school life. I attended a public university and completed the IB program. I graduated valedictorian and earned a 4.0 unweighted and 4.95 weighted GPA. Now it may seem like I had my college and future locked up with such good grades. Not really. GPA is only part of the equation, especially for college. My ACT/SAT was not the best 96th percentile. Extracurriculars and essay were strong. I earned a half-ride scholarship to a small in-state university. The top schools I was accepted to were UCLA and UC Berkeley. Other top universities rejected me. In the end many students in my grade, with worse GPA’s, ended up going to schools like Notre Dame, USC, Brown, Carnegie Mellon. Others even got full rides just because they got a 35 on the ACT and did JV tennis.  College: The importance of GPA in undergraduate school depends on a few factors. If you want to make the deans list then you have to carry an above average GPA, probably 3.75 to make the cut. Graduate school really cares about GPA, so many qualified candidates are competing for a spot at some of the best programs at the top universities in the world. Some jobs/internships also care about what GPA you earned in college. I also know that you have to carry a strong GPA to study abroad by junior year. College is an experience, it’s more than just grades.

They definitely matter, though they’re not everything either. I know that’s a wishy washy answer, but to summarize, the more academic your goals are, the more important grades are. For getting into college for example, getting good grades is one of the key factors that could get you admission into selective colleges, or get you scholarships. Becoming a tenured professor, especially at a prestigious university, usually requires a great academic record. To get into a good PHD program one has to get good college grades which required good grades in high school. For careers outside academia, GPA in your more recent degree is typically less important. In fact, I heard google no longer relies on GPA when hiring, saying it correlates little with job success. For many other jobs, they may be willing to accept a decent GPA, perhaps 3.0 or above in the American scale. Past that, it’s more up to networking and the interview. But many jobs, including professional ones, don’t care about gpa very much at all, if you got the degree. This means that for a lot of people, the importance of gpa will look something like this, again in the USA: In high school grades are reasonably important if you plan on going to college. Decent grades are necessary to get into a good college and scholarships. In college grades are still important if you plan on going to graduate school. Otherwise, not necessarily as much. In graduate school, it depends more on the context but grades on the whole get less important further, given after this many folks go into industry. Typically, the last degree before your job is the one where grades actually matter the least. They still matter enough you’d want decent grades, say a b average. Though take this all with a grain of salt, I’m talking about the USA general context. Elsewhere I’m not sure. And some careers I’ve heard do put more of an emphasis on GPA than most, like law.

In most of the cases, Yes. In a few cases, No. If you are planning to go for M.Tech, a higher GATE score is most likely to overshadow a weaker GPA. There are very few PSUs which take students directly on the basis of GATE score. Otherwise, candidates are called for interviews on the basis of their GATE score wherein their profile is evaluated. If you are planning to go for MS/PhD, it is natural for you to show your inclination in the field and a good GPA is the best metric to portray that. In case someone doesn't have a good GPA (and otherwise), your project work is also seen deeply and again, a good grade in Thesis project is an obvious metric to prove your interest and research. If you are looking to go for management studies, a bad GPA is heavily looked down upon. And not just your GPA, your 10th and 12th class percentage are also looked very seriously. Every year, despite scoring a great CAT percentile, people do not get calls from IIM A/B if they do not have a good GPA (typically 8+). Only IIMC comes to rescue in such cases because it doesn't consider graduation marks while evaluating profiles but you will still need a high 10th and 12th class percentage here. GPAs are taken way more seriously in B-schools compared to IITs (or engineering colleges). Some companies do not even take interviews for internships/placements other than the Top 10 (or so) Institute Rankers. Companies even try to get the ranks of the students from the institute (which is not known to the students) to make better decisions. If you are thinking in terms of job opportunities, the answer lies in a grey area. As much as it is obvious that any company would like to take a student with a higher GPA provided that the GPA earned is in the field of work that the company does, there are companies which value internships, extra-curriculars and positions of responsibility over GPA if the case is contrary. For e.g. A Civil Engineering student applying for a Business Analyst post, or Business Operations post, or in a bank. Now that the GPA has become irrelevant, the next thing a company would look into would be internships and PORs. So, that makes sense. However, there can be peculiar cases where companies may not prefer a student with a higher GPA even though the field matches. In such cases, companies think that the student may go for higher studies (M.Tech/MS/PhD) and will leave the job eventually. So, they hire students with less GPAs. However, such cases are very rare and mostly happen in PSUs or similar kind of jobs. GPA does reflect a lot about you, irrespective of any of the above case. A good GPA would naturally show your interest and dedication if you want to pursue the field further, otherwise, a good GPA shows that you are still good in doing things that you don't like. Work does get mundane/repetitive at times and any company would want a person who shows efficacy (and doesn't mess things up) even when he/she is not liking the work. To summarize, a good GPA can only do more good than harm. And your resume always looks better if you have it.

He had unfortunately chosen a major that was challenging and not aligned with his interests. This has given him a rocky start from his Freshman year that he had spent most of his college life working backwards from. Luckily, his current major, recent internship, and skill set was a perfect match for the role the recruiter had been seeking. Even she understood that it would be silly to refuse him a chance because of a simple number that he could clearly explain. Long story short is that - if an alignment fits, the GPA will be one of many variables considered. If an alignment is on the fence, the GPA is definitely a good reflection of whether you are a good investment. While your focus should be on a good GPA, if you have a perfect idea of what you want to do and how you can get there, it can be overlooked in favor of this alignment.

The only time that GPA matters is if what you want requires it. Otherwise it is another set of measurement that has not relevance at all. If you are talking about college GPA, you have two: cumulative and major. The cumulative is used by the Graduate School as a minimum and the major GPA (the average of major upper division courses) is used by the Department. Both GPAs are a measure of how well you have done in your coursework and an indicator is that you are ready to do graduate work. The GRE is a measure that compares applicants to one another relative to one another. It allows for a standard comparison. It also is another factor in evaluating the applicants ability to do graduate coursework. A high GRE score will make up for a low cumulative GPA but not for a low major GPA. A GRE Subject Test if available makes up for a low major GPA. The SOP supported by LORs is the most important consideration since it is the only information that indicate whether or not an applicant can write a thesis that may include original research. Having a network of references is important because as with most things in life, it is what you know and who you know that will determine whether or not you get what you want.

There is no black or white answer to this question. From my personal experience, more than 80% of time grades do not decide your future. But there are certain instances where grades do help you to get good opportunities, that’s why I would give only 20% weight in favor of grades. I was 6.47/10 GPA and stood 46 out of 69 people in my class of engineering studies. Still, I managed to land a job at top companies like Deloitte and PwC in the United States. I am not saying that I have achieved something extraordinary but I am at least matching career standards with my batch toppers or doing better than most of my classmates. Well, did a low GPA help me? Definitely not, it was certainly not very easy for me to land my first job out of engineering school. If I had a better GPA, I would have got opportunities to interview with companies who only consider top 10% students of the batch. Needless to say, the salary offered by these companies is far better than those who prefer candidates with a lower GPA. Good grades definitely allow you to access initial opportunities. For this reason, I would assign 20% weight to good grades.  Let me tell you why grades do not solely decide someone’s future or career accomplishments. More time to explore your superpowers: Students who are not solely focused to getting marks often spend their time innovating and exploring hidden opportunities. During engineering studies, I spent my time learning tricks of digital marketing. Today, digital marketing is very common but it was a pretty new concept back in 2008-2009. It helped me promote some of my initial ventures without spending a single penny. Broader opportunities: When your mark sheet doesn’t reflect great grades, people consider you for tasks and opportunities which are different from monotonous technical work. My manager always focused on utilizing my soft skills like communication skills, presentation, and negotiation skills. Even my SOP for the US universities was more inclined toward my extra-curricular activities and business skills. That was the major reason I was able to get admission at Duke University with 6.47 GPA.Nobody cares about GPA after 2 years: As soon as you join the corporate world, there are multiple factors decide your progress like your problem-solving ability, communication skills, team building ability, leadership quality, and quick learning ability. Nobody cares about how much you scored in school. Here, life takes a completely new highway where you meet a thousand other people from all over the world and you can’t compete with them just based on your GPA. Entrepreneurs don’t need GPA: If you aspire to be your own boss then you do not need a great GPA, not even at the first step of your venture. As I mentioned in the first point, you need to spend time exploring your hidden talent which grades will never reflect.That said, don’t be a part of the rat race. If you love studies and you love to get good grades, then definitely study hard. But if you have goals in a career which do not directly relate to your grades, focus on building your overall personality and build the network. Enjoy what you do, I promise you will surely succeed. Good luck!

Let me answer this in two parts (1) Does GPA matter? Does a rating of 4 or above matter for a product/ seller on Amazon? Hell yes, it does. Does a rating of 4 or above on Amazon matter if you are selling in an offline market? Well, not really. The answer to your question is a classic consulting/ MBA ‘it depends’. A good GPA is essentially a signal to the market that you work hard, are consistent with your effort and have high degree of skill in whatever your academic major was. This is only important if you plan to enter a market that values GPA with some degree of confidence (since all markets discount GPA by a certain percentage and hence you have an interview process). So if you want to become a sportsperson, a musician or a businessman, your GPA doesn’t really matter. But in case you want to live a more ‘regular’ life with a job or want to pursue higher studies, unfortunately my friend, GPA does matter. (2) Does high GPA ensure you’ll make it big? The evidence here is slightly sketchy. As I said, high GPA does imply that you work hard, are sharp and are consistent with your efforts. These are characteristics you’d usually find in successful people who’ve made it big in life. So it is the underlying set of characteristics and not the GPA itself that helps you make it big in life. Having said this, a good GPA does give you a better launchpad (and hence a time advantage) as compared to your peers if you plan to enter a market that values GPA.

Everybody knows that keeping your GPA up in high school is important. But exactly how important is your GPA once you’re in college? The GPA is calculated by averaging your grades together based on a point system, which is usually a 4.0 scale. There are two types of college GPAs: semester GPA and cumulative GPA. The semester GPA represents the student’s progress for that specific semester, while the cumulative GPA displays the student’s academic standing for their courses since matriculation into the college. How is GPA Calculated? Most colleges count only courses that were taken at that specific college. There are some exceptions to this rule. For instance, Wells College in New York will also count courses taken at an affiliated off-campus program, at Cornell University, Ithaca College and Cayuga Community College, toward the cumulative GPA. This means that if you are a transfer student you leave your old GPA behind to start a new one from scratch. When calculating a student’s GPA, a college generally does not count grades of F, Incomplete, or Pass/Fail. But this is not always the rule, as Thomas Edison State College recently passed the policy that these grades will be reflected on a student’s GPA. A report in US News & World Report shows the five lowest and highest GPAs by major. Science, technology, engineering and mathematics majors have the lowest GPAs - perhaps because professors tend to grade harder or simply because those areas of study are more demanding academically. Programs in the arts and humanities such as music, English and language have higher average GPAs. This may be because professors tend to be more lenient in grading because the work is often subjective. How to Raise Your College GPA Here are some helpful tips on how you can earn a high GPA in college: Learn good study habits. Don’t wait until the last minute to cram. Instead, study in short periods each day. This is half the battle in achieving good grades in your courses.Show up to every class. Attendance can be a percentage of the grade.Be organized. Know when tests will be held and projects are due.Take a full course load. Don’t take only classes that you know you’ll get an A in. Challenge yourself with harder courses that may be weighted differently.GPA After College The importance of your GPA after college depends on your plans. If you want to go to graduate school or medical school, your GPA is going to matter, as admissions committees will look at your transcripts – much the same as for college admissions. If your grades were low during your freshman and sophomore years but improved during your junior and senior year, this could help you. Many graduate schools focus on GPA earned as a junior and senior. According to US News & World Report, maintaining a high GPA is essential to being accepted at top graduate schools such as Harvard Medical School (3.8 GPA), Yale Law (3.9) or Stanford Business School (3.6). If you plan on entering the job market immediately after graduation, it is advisable to list your GPA on your resume – that is assuming it is a respectable number. Employers may take into consideration a student’s GPA as they are weeding through stacks of resumes. Don’t worry if you didn’t have a high GPA. This is not the only criteria employers look at when considering applicants. Internships, other work experience, relevant projects in college and other extracurricular activities also weigh heavily on entry-level positions. It’s rumored that Google won’t hire anyone from any school unless they have a 3.0 GPA. But Gayle Laakmann McDowell, author of The Google Resume: How to Prepare for a Career and Land a Job at Apple, Microsoft, Google or Any Top Tech Company, said three out of the eight people she worked with at Google did not have college degrees at all.

Do grades (GPA) really matter? Hours of repetitive practice and learning by rote are often encouraged so as to maximize scores. While one does learn this way, the objective becomes that of test success rather than learning and being able to apply it effectively. In the industry (away from schools/universities), test scores aren’t as important as they’re made out to be. However, they remain a very important benchmark for evaluating a fresh out of school student; that of their ability to perform within a system. Those who are a part of the system are noticed if they can do well within it. That’d require a certain extent of effort, and the will to do things that might well be boring or outright distasteful, but need to be done, and done well at that. Thus, grades are important, but more as a sign that you’re willing to get the job done than as a sign of one’s knowledge. Grades alone aren’t everything, but they’re an important aspect. Something I want tattooed on my forehead is “grades don’t matter.” The current perception of the importance of grades in academia dumbfounds me, because I think that by caring too much about grades, most students are missing the point of education. A college education is often cited as a prerequisite for a “good job” out in “the real world” (both terms that I hate). With this understanding of the importance of college, many students get wrapped up in their grades, often taking them as value statements on their own self-worth. It’s really easy to get trapped in the cycle of getting good grades to get a good job to make a lot of money to pay for a house to support a family to send your own kids to college so they can get a good job and make lots of money. When this happens, grades become the foundation for an entire future — and perhaps even the foundation of your child’s future, which is honestly just way too much pressure. Aside from wanting to take some pressure off myself, I maintain that grades really aren’t that important because I value education for more than its spot on my résumé. The reason I’m in college isn’t to get a good job later. I would be here even if I knew I would never, ever get a job, because I think that college is worth something much more important than some money later on. I think that education is about better knowing yourself, better knowing the world around you, and attempting to figure out your place in the world. Understanding reality and your role in it (“Knowing thyself,” as the ancient Greeks said), is infinitely more valuable than any material consequences of a diploma. Education is about self-improvement, not about the number of zeros on the end of a paycheck. With this in mind, I think that grades start to lose their novelty. By valuing education for its personal return instead of its financial return, grades become less of a statement on the future and more of a (mostly) inconsequential part of knowing thyself. None of this is to say that it isn’t important to work hard in school, which will often produce good grades, as working hard is part of improving yourself. What this means is that there is no need to get in a huff about a disappointing grade here or there: it isn’t a comment on self-value, and it isn’t a comment on projected success out in “the real world” (as opposed to this world, the fake one). Grades have their place. They’re a necessary part of education. What they aren’t a necessary part of is self-esteem. They don’t really matter because they don’t define us: what defines us is the changes education makes within us. So maybe I got a B or a C on that last exam, but am I better overall for having taken the class? The answer is usually yes. And that is what makes education worthwhile. Forget the grades, forget the jobs, and just try to become a better person, enjoying the ridiculous luxury that education is.

For graduate school admissions or jobs, GPA matters. To get a good GPA in a subject, a student has to learn concepts in a particular subject and then do very well in the various assessments in the course (e.g., homework, tests, final exam, term paper, project). This is learning proficiency. The student has to do this in every single course to end up with a great GPA. This is long-term consistency. Thus, the GPA measures learning proficiency in your subject and long-term consistency. In grad school or jobs, you have a similar scenario. The supervisor assigns tasks (at least in the early stage) with the expectation to become proficient in the tasks and deliver on time. Again, your ability to do well depends on your learning proficiency and consistency. At the early stages of student life, GPA is a great measure of your ability to be proficient and consistent. Thus the GPA is used to filter great students from the not-so-great. As time goes on, the GPA matters less. For example, to get a job after Ph.D., you do not need a stellar GPA but only a good research portfolio.

I will give a brief background about me before answering. I hold a B TECH degree in Computer Science and Engineering from Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Technological University. Raigad. Maharashtra. We had an aggregate CGPA system in our college. Our university was autonomous and hence had its own rules and regulation with regards to exam and grading system. They had their own formulae and logic and GPA to percentage conversion formula. I was an average student (or rather below average I would say) during by graduation. So as per our university the one having an aggregate CPGA of 6.5 considering the count of all 8 semester, would be classified as a ‘First Class’ Engineer. Right from the first year I knew I had to be above the least or else I would land in no job state. Some how I failed achieving it and at the end of 3rd Year my CGPA was 6.31. Now in the 1st semester of final year I could manage only 6.86 SGPA and now CPGA became 6.38 considering 7 semesters. To make it above 6.5 I had to score at least 7.3 SGPA or above in the final (8th) semester . I had a lot of pressure as I was not holding any job till my 7th semester. I was not fitting the company criteria and for some I was not technically sound enough. So I just focused on the final semester and hopefully was able to make the required. I scored 8.3 SGPA and my CPGA became 6.60. I was marginally way ahead of what I expected. Well now what? I got the degree of a First Class Engineer though my parents expected the next honor(distinction) though. I was neither having any job offer nor I could opt for higher education due to some other reasons. I went on doing CDAC(Centre for Development of Advanced Computing - Wikipedia) and prepared for companies. I was finally able to get into Industry though but the realities of IT industries got clear. Now the real answer to the question asked can be answered for two situations. A — If you managed to score above the basic requirement. Percentage and grades only matter till the point you reach your interview phase. It’s very rare some will judge you based on your percentage, though he might ask the reason for low performances in exams, but he wont reject on that basis. It’s completely under your control how you drive the interview. But definitely a good grade graph can be impressive and will show your consistency. So you need to be good enough to answer their questions. B — If you failed to score above the basic requirement. In such situation it becomes tough to reach to the interview phase and your name would be cut off from the criteria. But when some organisation keeps and open invitation to all level grades than you have the chance, but as far as I have seen when all are invited definitely the process is tough compare to prior, just to filter. So you have to be very strong with your skill as getting another chance is tough. To conclude. It’s just that you should cross the line, it’s ok if you didn’t come first second third or any position but try not to fail. So grades do matter but it’s not that only grades matter. It’s your skill that matter the most.
